data.title: Move some hard-coded shortcuts to application menu
data.body:
Some features such as reload current window, are hard-coded in `OnKeyEvent`, I moved them into menubar so when you press corresponding shortcuts you can see visual feedbacks on menubar.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-21 at 10 54 31 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/639601/286231/4cc4d5ac-9237-11e2-8d05-7aba16239804.png)
![Screen Shot 2013-03-21 at 10 54 42 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/639601/286232/51128460-9237-11e2-9f66-47cb67f911d3.png)
![3](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/639601/286212/f2e7a2f8-9236-11e2-9c32-b59cfa6471c9.png)

data.title: Atom got into a weird state for github/atom project
data.body:
I'm not sure exactly what I did to get into this weird state, but part of it was Command-R while a Markdown preview was open.

After the reload the tab bars where gone and only the two panes (markdown file and markdown preview) where visible. Reloading again didn't change anything, so I closed the project and tried to reopen it again, but it fails (just a empty gray window) with the following error in the inspector:

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'left' of undefined
    at module.exports.Editor.positionLeftForLineAndColumn (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:1851:45)
    at module.exports.Editor.pixelPositionForScreenPosition (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:1823:19)
    at module.exports.CursorView.getPixelPosition (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/cursor-view.coffee:94:26)
    at module.exports.CursorView.updateDisplay (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/cursor-view.coffee:71:28)
    at module.exports.Editor.updateCursorViews (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:1386:36)
    at module.exports.Editor.updateDisplay (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:1362:12)
    at module.exports.Editor.resetDisplay (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:1341:19)
    at module.exports.Editor.afterAttach (/Users/mutle/github/atom/src/app/editor.coffee:907:12)
    at callAttachHook (/Users/mutle/github/atom/vendor/space-pen.coffee:266:107)
    at jQuery.fn.(anonymous function) [as append] (/Users/mutle/github/atom/vendor/space-pen.coffee:282:9) index.html:23
window.onload index.html:23

Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 403 (Forbidden) https://api.github.com/markdown

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'left' of undefined index.html:1851
```

The "Failed to load resource" seems to be since I hit an API limit (probably because I did some testing with markdown preview).

data.title: Update markdown preview when markdown buffer is saved
data.body: So you don't have to press meta-m all the time.

data.title: Load grammars from atom packages
data.body:
Currently grammars can only be loaded from textmate packages.

Should also include prefs and other textmate package file.

data.title: Load snippets with async I/O instead of in a background thread
data.body: Most of the time we were saving was from the blocking read operations, so this avoids that blocking without requiring us to use a worker thread. We're trying to get rid of all background workers for now so we can drop Cheng's support for using Node in worker threads since it introduces thread-safety problems that could crash Atom.

data.title: Speed up search results
data.body:
Search is slow, but the bottleneck is not on the native side. The major speed killer is creating the Dom result elements. While searching for `repo` in github/github, executing the search takes ~51ms, creating the operations\* takes ~5200ms and rendering the results to the Dom takes ~25,000ms.

Here is what needs to be done:
- [x] Incrementally build and append result elements
- [x] Make operation creation quicker
- Operations are JS objects that hold data for each result

data.title: Improve search behavior: a conversation with code
data.body:
I'm really interested in improving the search experience. Much of my behavior, whether I'm in an unfamiliar codebase or just trying to mass-update some content, revolve around search. I'd love Atom to duplicate, at a minimum, the capabilities found in other editors.

In this PR, I've got an extraordinarily basic set of functionality working: non-RegExp searches, case sensitive searches, and whole word searches. What I'm most concerned about is validating whether I'm comprehending how search works. Here's what I'm observing:
1. Search latches onto the command panel, which uses Sam syntaxes
2. When you fire off a search, you call the command interpreter, which  takes a look at _commands.pegjs_ to determine what it is you want to do
3. After realizing you want to search, a new `RegexAddress` is constructed, and executed

My confusion comes from how to correctly pass along options to `RegexAddress` in a sane manner. The way I'm doing it right now is kind of ugly: after clicking a button in the command-panel, [global options are set in `RegexAddress`](https://github.com/github/atom/blob/8fbef8e598ea37ea277089cc1fad2fb0f7bfea48/src/packages/command-panel/lib/command-panel-view.coffee#L149-L150). Every time a search is executed, [those options are read](https://github.com/github/atom/blob/8fbef8e598ea37ea277089cc1fad2fb0f7bfea48/src/packages/command-panel/lib/commands/regex-address.coffee#L20-L25). 

I feel like there's a better way to do this.

Pending items:
- [ ] Implement a sane way to inject options into search
- [ ] Get proper Octicons for search options (file an issue to get these added?)
- [ ] Add CSS for `active` and `hover` states
- [ ] Add tooltips (is it possible to use non-native tooltips?)
- [ ] Write tests

P.S. I have so many other concerns about the Sam syntax--like, should a user that hits `Ctrl-F` be able to delete the starting `/` or `Xx/`? Should there be a "reset" button? Should there be more UI options for choices like `,x/` or replacing content? I really have a soft spot for Plan 9 (though I'm more familiar with Acme :smirk_cat:); I just think every function accessible to the keyboard-typing crowd should be there for the mouse-clicking crowd.

data.title: Markdown preview should replace pane (not whole window)
data.body:
Markdown preview is hella baller. Can we make it even ballerer? Mayhaps. Here's my desired workflow for Great Justice Markdown Editing:
1. Open Markdown file.
2. Split pane to the right.
3. Switch to Markdown preview on right pane.
4. Edit in left pane and hit save.
5. Have Markdown preview in right pane auto-detect and re-render.

This is only possible if the Markdown preview only replaces the pane of the Markdown file, and not the entire window (as is current behavior). This is how I'd expect it to work anyhow, even outside of a split-pane workflow.

data.title: Support optional doc strings for commands
data.body:
This PR changes `jQuery.fn.command` from a straight `on` passthrough to something a little more specific.

The new signature is `command(eventName, selector, options, handler)`. This signature clarifies usage a bit: Unlike `on`, `command` takes a single event name. `selector` and `options` are optional.

The `options` object can have two keys:
- `data`, an Object passed through to `on`. This isn't used very often, but it's there.
- `doc`, a String to replace the auto-generated docstring for an event.

The `doc` key is only used to replace the portion of an event name after the `:`.

Before:

``` coffeescript
@command "testing:show-alert", ->
  # => "Testing: Show Alert
```

After:

``` coffeescript
@command "testing:show-alert", doc: "Hi!", ->
  # => "Testing: Hi!"
```

I also dropped a little tweak in to always change `github` to `GitHub` if it's an event namespace. :octocat:

data.title: On cefode branch, subsequent refreshes slower than initial load
data.body:
When you first load cefode Atom in stable mode (not `--dev`), it takes about 1 second to load according to the timing that we log to the console. Subsequent refreshes take ~2.5 seconds. We've also noted that Node's require is quite a bit slower than Atom's original home-grown require in all cases.

data.title: Use absolute paths inside fuzzy-finder
data.body:
This isn't quite ready. `FuzzyFinderView` is changed to deal in absolute paths except when actually rendering, which makes it a lot easier to deal with things like edit sessions on files outside the project root.

Before this change, choosing a file outside the project root from the buffer list would raise an exception.

The path display for stuff that's not in the project needs to be a bit better: Right now I'm just blindly calling `project.relativize` on everything instead of checking to see if the path is actually under the project root.

/cc @defunkt
